Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Simulation-Based Policy Analysis for Reducing Ebola Transmission Risk in Air Travel

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The researchers on this project will build fine-scale simulation models for infection spread during air travel in order to identify the causes of infection spread, as well as procedures and policies that will limit its spread without major disruption to air travel. The researchers propose to create a super-computing based application that will provide useful insight to decision makers - such as medical responders, policy makers etc. dealing with Ebola. The models can be applied at the level of individual flights; thus not only can the spread of Ebola be understood for a particular flight, but also procedures can be developed that will limit the infection risk for that flight.

An air-transport model, which operates at the level of individual flights, will be integrated with a phylogeographic model (that captures the historical processes responsible for the existing geographic distributions of individuals) in order to analyze the spread of infection between geographic regions when potentially infected populations are being transported into, out of and across regions, by air travel. The result of this work will help identify policy as well as operational solutions to reduce the risk of a pandemic, and also set up scalable software capabilities on a readily available infrastructure that can be used to address the current Ebola pandemic, as well as respond quickly to new emergencies.

This proposal integrates the PIs? combined expertise in modeling human movement in planes, modeling the spread of infections, building a software infrastructure for decision support, and large-scale parallel computing. The models will be integrated using the Complex Systems framework (CSF, developed by a member of the proposing team) that provides a comprehensive decision support environment for analysis. Through this project, and in addition, CSF?s scalability will be enhanced to petascale machines, and methods will be developed to reduce the large computational cost of these simulations.

Results of this work will provide valuable insight to policy makers. In particular, fine grain questions regarding plane travel can be asked and answered, such as: (a) the risk air travel has on disease spread to neighboring regions (b) can a change to another type of a plane lead to reduced risk of transmission? (c) Do certain seating arrangement or changes to boarding and disembarkation processes reduce the likelihood of transmission?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Air travel has been identified as a leading factor in the spread of infections, such as influenza, and this had motivated calls for limitations on air travel in order to prevent the spread of the previous outbreak of Ebola. However, such limitations carry considerable economic and human costs. Consequently, it is necessary to evaluate the extent of impact of air travel on spread of Ebola and to also identify policy options that can mitigate its spread without major disruption to air travel. Computer simulations play a crucial role in evaluating viable policy options and exploring potential consequences of decisions taken by policy makers. The goal of this project was to create a software infrastructure based on massively parallel simulation to provide useful insight to decision makers dealing with Ebola.

Ebola is spread by contact with fluids of infected persons. Seating arrangements and movement of passengers in the plane play a major role in such contact. Current models, to a large extent, operate at too coarse a scale to account for changes in human dynamics brought about by new policies, such as changes in boarding procedures. In our approach, we developed a fine-scaled human movement model to capture passenger movement in planes with different boarding and disembarkation procedures. We integrated this with a fine-scale Ebola transmission model to evaluate the spread of Ebola through individual flights. Such fine-scale modeling is a major advance in analysis of infection spread through air travel. In addition, we linked results from individual airports into a phylogeographic model to analyze the impact of local scale policy changes on larger scale spread of infection between geographic regions. Such linkage is another major intellectual development in epidemic modeling.

A significant impediment to such analysis is uncertainty in human behavior and lack of data, especially in the initial stages of an infection. In our approach, we dealt with this by parameterizing the sources of uncertainty and exploring different scenarios over the parameter space of the different possibilities. This helps identify vulnerabilities in different policy options in the presence of uncertainties. This approach leads to a large computational effort, which is particularly a bottleneck during emergencies. We dealt with this through massive parallelization on the Bluewaters supercomputer at NCSA, using novel parallelization strategies for this class of applications. We then integrated results from the massively parallel simulations into a decision support infrastructure that can help visualize the consequences of different policy options.

These intellectual advances led to insight with potential for broader impact on society, by suggesting policy or procedural choices that could lead to reduced likelihood of Ebola spread through flights. We showed changes to boarding and disembarkation procedures, seating arrangements, and planes sizes could substantially reduce the number of contacts between passengers. Among these, changes in boarding procedures and plane sizes could bring about a substantial decrease in the spread of infections. In particular, random boarding is preferable to zone-wise boarding in terms of reduction in infection spread, and small planes were preferable to large ones. Analysis by other researchers had suggested that if travel restrictions had not been imposed during the last Ebola outbreak, then there was a possibility of a small number of infected passengers boarding flights. Our model indicated that this could possibly generate additional infections during flights with current procedures. However, changing the boarding procedures or plane sizes could reduce the likelihood of such transmission substantially.
